etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French imputer, from Latin imputare ‘enter in the account’, from in- ‘in, towards’ + putare ‘reckon’

definitions: represent (something, especially something undesirable) as being done, caused, or possessed by someone; attribute
assign (a value) to something by inference from the value of the products or processes to which it contributes

examples.text: by imputing the interest rates they potentially introduce a measurement error

shortDefinitions: assign value to something by inference from value of products or processes

definitions: ascribe (righteousness, guilt, etc.) to someone by virtue of a similar quality in another

examples.text: Christ's righteousness has been imputed to us

shortDefinitions: ascribe (righteousness, guilt, etc.) to someone by virtue of similar quality in another
